{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient's symptoms of facial swelling, pitting edema of the extremities, and periorbital edema, along with the laboratory findings of hypoalbuminemia, hypercholesterolemia, and proteinuria, are indicative of nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome in children is most commonly caused by minimal change disease, which is characterized by effacement of the foot processes of the podocytes on electron microscopy. However, light microscopy findings are typically normal in minimal change disease, which is why it is called 'minimal change'. Therefore, the renal biopsy of this patient is most likely to show normal light microscopy findings.", "answer_choice": "D"}
